children.name: be in trouble
examples: ▪ It’s clear from these figures that the company is in trouble.
▪ When someone’s in trouble it’s natural to try and help them.

children.name: get into troublestart having serious problems
examples: ▪ I took out a loan but got into trouble when I lost my job.

children.name: in deep/serious/big troublehave very serious problems
examples: ▪ Consular officers can help and advise you if you are in any serious trouble while abroad.

children.name: be faced with
children.definition: to have a problem, a difficult choice, or the possibility of something bad happening soon: đương đầu với
examples: We are often faced with dilemmas or problems which have no easy answers.
Manufacturing industries are faced with decreasing productivity and increasing international competition.
When faced with an unfamiliar word, good readers are able to make guesses based on the meaning and structure of the sentence.

children.name: have a problem
examples: ▪ If you have any problems, just come and ask me.
▪ I had a few problems getting the copier to work.

children.name: have a problem with
examples: ▪ I’m having a bit of a problem with my dishwasher.
▪ One landowner says he has never had any problems with hikers crossing his property.
▪ Jane can be quite difficult to get on with -- I’ve had one or two problems with her in the past.

children.name: have trouble
children.definition: /difficulty  to have problems that make it more difficult to do something: có khăn khăn
examples: ▪ You look as if you’re having trouble -- do you want any help?

children.name: have trouble/difficulty with:có khăn khăn với
examples: ▪ I had some trouble with the car this morning.
▪ She’s having a little difficulty with her spelling.

children.name: have trouble/difficulty doing something:có khăn khăn khi làm cái gì đó
examples: ▪ He had a lot of trouble finding a job.
▪ The child was having difficulty breathing.

children.name: have a hard time
children.definition: to have a lot of problems or a lot of difficulty doing something: gặp khổ sở
examples: ▪ Premature babies have a hard time even under the best of circumstances.

children.name: have a hard time doing sth
examples: ▪ A lot of people are having a hard time making ends meet.
▪ Anyone calling the 202 area code this weekend had a hard time getting through.

children.name: be up against
children.definition: to have a difficult problem or opponent that you must deal with or fight against: ở trong tình trạng khó khăn
examples: ▪ The company is up against tough competition from abroad.
▪ When you’re surfing and get hit by a wave, it’s a reminder of what you’re up against.
▪ In the semi-finals he will be up against one of the best players in the game.

children.name: come up against
children.definition: to start having problems or difficulties that you have to deal with: phải đối mặt với
examples: ▪ Older people applying for jobs come up against an age barrier.
▪ The committee found itself coming up against the prejudices of many staff when it tried to introduce new working practices.

children.name: encounter
children.definition: to experience problems, difficulties, or opposition while you are trying to do something:
examples: gặp phải
▪ Drivers on the M25 are likely to encounter fog and black ice tonight.
▪ Many of the children encountered some difficulty in learning the material.
▪ The government has encountered strong opposition over its plans to build a new airport.
encounterverb[ T ]EXPERIENCE chạm trán;đụng độ;đọ sứcvoi
to experience, especially something unpleasant
_When did you first encounter these difficulties?
_The army is reported to be encountering considerable resistance.

children.name: run into problems/difficulties
children.definition: to unexpectedly start having problems while you are doing something: vướng vào nhiều rắc rối
examples: ▪ The corporation has run into serious financial problems.
▪ Our staff will be happy to answer your questions should you run into difficulties installing the equipment yourself.

children.name: have a lot on your plate
children.definition: to have a lot of difficult problems to deal with or a lot of things to worry about: có nhiều thứ để lo lắng
examples: ▪ Don’t bother your mother -- she’s got a lot on her plate at the moment.
▪ Susan’s had a lot on her plate recently, what with the car accident and everything.

children.name: to be in a very difficult situation
be in a mess
children.definition: /be a mess  to have so many problems that there is not much hope that things will get better, especially as a result of past mistakes:
examples: gặp nhiều rắc rối
▪ The previous manager had left the restaurant’s affairs in a terrible mess.
get into a mess
gặp nhiều rắc rối
▪ How did you manage to get into this mess in the first place?
somebody’s life is a messthey have a lot of problems and seem unable to deal with them
cuộc sống ai đó bị xáo trộn
▪ Her boyfriend left her and she lost her job - her life is just a mess at the moment.

children.name: be in a fix
children.definition: to be in a difficult situation and not know what to do: gặp rắc rối to
examples: ▪ The team’s owner is in a fix - he’s spent a lot to improve the stadium, but ticket sales are still declining.
▪ Wyck’s business consists of helping, for a fee, computer owners who are in a technical fix.

children.name: be in a tight corner
children.definition: be in a tight spot/corner  to be in a very difficult or dangerous situation, when there is very little you can do to get out of it: lâm vào hoàn cảnh khó khăn
examples: ▪ A mobile phone lets you reach help when you’re in a tight spot.
▪ O'Neill had been in tight corners before, but never as tight as this one.
put somebody in a tight spot
khiến ai đólâm vào hoàn cảnh khó khăn
give someone a difficult problem
▪ Losing his job put them in a tight spot financially.

children.name: be in a difficult position
children.definition: be in a difficult/awkward position  to be in a difficult situation because whatever you do, you are likely to offend someone or make things worse: lâm vào tình thế khó khăn
examples: ▪ I was in a difficult position, as I was being asked to confront a man who had much more power than I did.
put somebody in a difficult/awkward position
khiến ai đólâm vào tình thế khó khăn
▪ Clara was angry at Harry for putting her in such an awkward position.

children.name: be in an impossible position
children.definition: to be in an extremely difficult situation, because whatever you do there will certainly be serious trouble: ở trong tình thế nan giải
examples: ▪ I’m in an impossible position -- if I criticize him he may resign, but if I don’t he’ll end up ruining the whole project.
put somebody in an impossible position
khiến ai đóở trong tình thế nan giải
▪ By bringing his objections out into the open, the Chancellor has put the Prime Minister in an impossible position.

children.name: be in a quandary
children.definition: to be in a very difficult situation and not be able to decide what is the best thing for you to do: lâm vào tình thế khó khăn
examples: ▪ I was in a quandary - I didn’t know whether to tell the police or not.
▪ The government has got itself into a quandary over the new tax -- if they abandon it they will be seen as weak, if they keep it they will be very unpopular.

children.name: be in dire straits
children.definition: to have very serious problems, especially financial ones, which could have very serious results: trong điều kiện eo hẹp
examples: ▪ The company is in dire financial straits.
▪ The team is in such dire straits they’ve even considered selling their three best players.

children.name: it’s one thing after another
children.definition: say this when you have had a series of problems and you feel that these problems will never end: họa vô đơn chí
examples: ▪ It’s been one thing after another since I started renting out the place to students.
▪ It’s one thing after another with that stupid photocopier! What’s wrong with it now?
